entries.garage_d: Garages are a civic structure that mayors can place at Civic Policy II.  Just pull up on your speeder and select
from the radial menu on your vehicle.  Mayors can set a small tax on the garage services to help their city prosper.
entries.player_cities_d:
Players that want to band together for the purposes of society and common defense can form a Player City.  The following chapters describe how to set up and join a Player City.

Player Cities are administrated by an elected Mayor.  The Mayor must be a member of the Politician profession.  For information on this profession, look in the chapter 'Politician' under 'Professions, Advanced Professions'.
entries.theater_d: You must be a Master Dancer or Master Musician to place a Theater.
entries.hospital_d: You must be a Master Doctor or Master Combat Medic to place a Hospital.
entries.cantina_d: You must be a Master Dancer or Master Musician to place a Cantina.
entries.commercial_structures_d:
Commercial structures are placed by players in cities.  If the city is disbanded, commercial structures always remain.

A mayor can make a city require zoning rights.  If a city requires zoning rights, you will need to get permission to build in the city from the mayor or from a militia member.  They can use the /grantZoningRights command to give another player the ability to build in the city for 24 hours.
entries.st_d: The Mayor may place skill trainers using the /recruitSkillTrainer command.  These work like any other skill trainer in the game.
entries.mt_d: The Mayor may place mission terminals using the /installMissionTerminal command.  A Mayor with Martial Planning IV may place faction aligned terminals.
entries.decorations_d: Architects can create a wide range of simple decorations like fountains, statues, and streetlamps that may be placed in the city by the mayor.  These decorations cannot be placed too close to structures.
entries.shuttleport_d: A shuttleport that allows planetary travel.  Players may travel to this shuttleport as well as buy tickets for other locations.  The mayor can levy a travel ticket fee that is paid on top of the normal ticket price.
entries.gardens_d:
Gardens are decorative structures that come in small, medium, and large sizes.  Most gardens have planetary restrictions, but exotic gardens from Dantooine, Dathomir, and Endor may be placed on any planet.

To destroy a garden, you can either use the small access terminal located in the garden's corner, or stand in the center of the garden and type /destroyStructure.
entries.cloning_d: The cloning facility works like any other cloning facility.  Players can buy insurance here and clone themselves for respawning on death.
entries.city_hall_d: The core of the city.  If this structure is removed the city is disbanded and all other civic structures in the city radius are removed.  This structure hosts the city management terminal where city policies are adjusted.
entries.bank_d: A small outdoor kiosk with three banking terminals.  If the bank is removed, players can get their items from any other bank on the planet.
entries.civic_structures_d: Civic structures are owned by the city and their maintenance is paid weekly from the city treasury.  These structures are placed directly by the mayor of the city.
entries.city_structures_d:
There are two types of city structures.

1. Civic structures are owned by the city and their maintenance is paid weekly from the city treasury.  These structures are placed directly by the mayor of the city.

2. Commercial structures are owned by other players, but permission to place them must be granted by the mayor.

The following sections cover these two types of structures.
entries.run_city_d: City administration is performed via the 'City Management Terminal' located in the City Hall.  Each of the sections below discuss different aspects of the city management.
entries.spec_d:
As the politician gains skills he will eventually earn a City Specialization (spec).  A city can only have one spec in place at a time.  A spec gives the city a bonus in some area at the exchange of an increased maintenance cost.  The city spec may only be changed once a week.

An example of a spec is 'Manufacturing Center'.  This spec increases the city hall maintenance by 20k credits / week.  Any crafting done in a 'Manufacturing Center' earns a 10% bonus to prototype assembly results, significantly reducing the chance of failures.

There are other city specs that can be read about by the Mayor at the city management terminal.

When you enter a city, you will receive a message indicating the name of the city, its rank, and any city specializations that city has.
